div1.p: In the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Application of Antonio Bisegna, alias Disegna, for Writ of Habeas Corpus } No. 2679 Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
To the Honorable Jeremiah Neterer, Judge of the United States District Court of the Western District of Washington, Northern Division:
The petition of Antonio Bisegna respectfully represents and shows to this honorable court as follows:

I. That your petitioner is unjustly and unlawfully detained and imprisoned in the King County jail in the City of Seattle in said County, State of Washington, by the United States Commissioner of Immigration.

II. That your petitioner is a white person, born in the Province of Aquila, Northern Italy, and left his native country of his own free will and not by any reason of having committed any offense against the laws of said country, and lawfully entered the United States on Feburary 14, 1908, and has ever since made this country his place of residence; that on April 17, 1910, he left certain of his personal affects in said City of Seattle and temporarily went to British Columbia, Deominion of Canda, where he remained until October 22, 1913, when he returned to said City of Seattle.

III. Your petitioner further shows that he is of sound mind, in good health, ablebodied and able to take care of himself, and has ever had sufficient funds to meet all the requirements of
the laws of the United States, and did not enter the United States as a contract laborer.

IV. Your petitioner further shows that he has not been been convicted of or admitted having committed a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude, and that he is not held by said Immigration Commssioner upon any final process issued by a Court of common jurisdiction or held upon any process or order for any contempt of any Court, officer or body hving authority to commit or hold him, nor upon any warrant issued by any court of this State upon indictment or infomration in this State, nor is there any lawful or valid reason for the detention of your petitioner.

V. That your petitioner is held by the said Commissioner of Immigration upon the alleged ground that he was a person likely to become a public charge at the time of his entry into the United States as shown by a copy of the warrant of arrest hereto annexed, but your petitioner avers that the time and place of entry into the United States is not as set forth in said warrant, but as hereinbefore set forth, and that he was at the time of entry and now is able to secure and save harmless the United States from any damage of any kind and nature whatsoever arising from (2)
inability of your petitioner to support and take care of himself, and that he is amply able and willing and intends to be a good and selfsupporting resident of the United States.

VI Your petitioner further represents that he was not given a fair and impartial hearing, as is contemplated by law; that the Immigration officials and inspectors were biased and prejudiced and are attempting to do indirectly what they could not do directly, in that your petitioner believes that the evidence upon which said officials bases their charge was the commission of an assual on the third degree, as defined by the statute of the State of Washington, a misdemeanor not involving moral turpitude, by this petitioner after his entry into the United States and for which your petitioner was not responsible; that the special examining board and Secretary of Labor and said Commissioner exceeded their authority and jurisdiction and acted in an arbitrary manner and that there is no evidence to bring this petitioner within the excluded classes at the time of his entry, but all of the evidence is to the contrary and shows that your petitioner had entered the United States more than three years prior to the issuance of the warrant of arrest herein, which warrant was issued contrary to and without any foundation in law, and that your petitioner is not amendable to the law which is the basis for the issuance of said warrant.
Wherefore your petitioner prays:

1. That a Writ of Habeas Corpus issue out of this Court directed to Henry M. White, the said Commissioner of Immigration, in whose custody your petitioner now is, commanding and requiring said Commissioner to have the body of your petitioner before this Court on some special and convenient day to be determined (3)
by this court, and then and there to show cause why this petitioner is detained of his liberty, and why he should not be forthwith and immediatel discharged from said custody.
II. That the pending of the return of this Writ at the date so to be fixed by this court to assure his appearance at the said return day.
III. That your petitioner be discharged from said custody and that he have such other and further relief as this court may deem just.
United States of America, Western District of Washington. }ss:

Antonio Bisegna, being first duly sworn deposes and says: That he is the petitioner named in the foregoing petition subscribed by him; that he has had read the same to him, knows the contents thereof and believes the same to be true.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 16th day of Feburary, 1914.
div1.ab: Louis E. Shela Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle, Wash.
div1.p: Warrant - Arrest of Alien
United States of America Department Washington Labor
To Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration, Seattle, Washington, Or to any Immigrant Inspector in the service of the United States.

Whereas, from evidence submitted to me, it appears that the alien Antonio Bisegna, alias Disegna, who landed at the port of Seattle, Washington, ex SS "Princess Victoria", on the 22nd day of Oct. 1913, has been found in the United States in violation of the Act of Congress approved Feburary 20, 1907, amended by the Act approved March 26, 1910, to wit:
That the said alien is a member of the excluded classes in that he was a person likely to become a public charge at the time of his entry into the United States,

I, Louis F. Post, Acting, Secretary of Labor, by virtue of the power and authority vested in me by the laws of the Untied States, do hereby command you to take into custody the said alien and grant him a hearing to enable him to show cause why he should not be deported in conformity with law.

The expenses of detention hereunder, if necessary, are authorized, payable from the appropriation "Expenses of Regulating Immigration, 1914",. Pending disposition of his case the alien may be released from custody upon furnishing satisfactory bond in the sum of $500.00.
For so doing, this shall be your sufficient warrant. Witness my hand and seal this 5th day of December, 1913.
div1.ab: (SD) Louis F. post, Acting Secretary of Labor.
div1.p: 2x No.
In the District Court of the United Sates for the Western District of Washington Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Application of Antonio Bisegna, alias Disegna, for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Filed in the U.S. District Court, Western Dist. of Washington. Northern Division FEB 16 1914 Frank L Crosby, Clerk, By EML Deputy
Service of papers in this case may be made upon Alfred H. Lundin and Louis E. Shela, Attorneys for petitioner. at No. Street Room 811 Lowman Bldg., Block Seattle, Washington.
Lowman & Hanford Co., Seattle, Wash. - Form No. 102
